desc: This class allows you to build commands for Minecraft.

desc: This sets the function to be executed when the command is executed,
this should have the correct amount of parameters for the command

params.desc: the function to execute

desc: This adds a child CommandBuilder to your command builder

params.name: childBuilder
params.desc: the child command builder to add

returns.desc: the parent command builder

to see all the different types refer to CommandBuilder.fromMap(...)

params.desc: the name of the argument

params.name: argumentType

returns.desc: the argument builder

static_methods.name: argument
desc: Creates an argument builder with a specific argument type, a name, and a default value
to see all the different types refer to CommandBuilder.fromMap(...)

params.name: argumentName
params.desc: the name of the argument

params.name: argumentType
params.desc: the type of the argument

params.name: suggestions
params.desc: a list of strings for the suggestions for the argument

returns.desc: the argument builder

static_methods.name: fromMap
desc: Creates an argument builder from a map.
The map must contain a 'name' key as a String that is the name of the command,
the map then can contain 'subcommands' as a map which contains the subcommands,
the key of the subcommands is the name of the subcommand, and the value is a map,
if the name is encased in '<' and '>' it will be treated as an argument, otherwise it will be treated as a literal.
You can chain arguments by leaving a space in the name like: 'literal <arg>'.
If the key has no name and is just an empty string the value will be used as the function
which will be executed when the command is executed, the function should have the appropriate
number of parameters, the number of parameters is determined by the number of arguments.
Argument types are defined in the main map under the key 'arguments' with the value of a map
the keys of this map should be the names of your arguments used in your subcommands,
this should be a map and must have the key 'type' which should be a string that is the type of the argument.
Optionally if the type is of 'integer' or 'double' you can also have the key 'min' and 'max' with numbers as the value,
and if the type is of 'enum' you must have the key 'enum' with the enum class type as the value: 'enum': MyEnum.type.
You can also optionally have 'suggests' which has the value of a list of strings that are suggestions for the argument.
You can also optionally have 'suggester' which has the value of a function that will be called to get suggestions for the argument,
this function should have arbitrary number of parameters which will be the arguments that the user has entered so far.
The possible argument types are: 'PlayerName', 'Word', 'GreedyString', 'Double', 'Integer', 'Boolean', 'Enum',
'ItemStack', 'Particle', 'RecipeId', 'EntityId', 'EnchantmentId'

params.name: argumentMap
params.desc: the map of arguments

returns.desc: the argument builder

static_methods.name: literal
desc: Creates a literal argument with just a string

params.name: argument
params.desc: the literal argument

returns.desc: the argument builder

static_methods.name: fromListOfMap
desc: Creates a config from a list of config maps

params.name: list
params.desc: The list of config maps

returns.desc: A list of configs created from the list of config maps

static_methods.name: fromMap
desc: Creates a config from a map
The map must contain the following keys:
'type' which is the type of the config which can be 'boolean', 'cycle', 'double', 'double_slider', 'integer', 'integer_slider', 'list', or 'string',
'name' which is the name of the config
And can optionally contain the following keys:
'description' which is a description of the config,
'optional_info' which is an optional info for the config,
'default_value' which is the default value of the config,
'category' which is the category of the config,
'value' which is the current value of the config,
'listener' which is a function that will be called when the config changes, this must have 1 parameter which is the rule that was changed,
'max_length' which is the max length for the input of the config, this must be an integer > 0, default is 32
And 'cycle' types must contain the following keys:
'cycle_values' which is a list of values that the config can cycle through.
And slider types must contain the following keys:
'min' which is the minimum value of the slider,
'max' which is the maximum value of the slider

params.name: map
params.desc: The map to create the config from

returns.desc: The config created from the map

Java.name: Java
desc: This class wraps Java values allowing for interactions between Java and Arucas.
This class cannot be instantiated or extended but you can create Java values by
using the static method 'Java.valueOf()' to convert Arucas to Java

methods.name: callMethod
deprecated: You should call the method directly on the value: Java.valueOf('').isBlank();
desc: This calls the specified method with the specified parameters, calling the method
with this function has no benefits unless you are calling a function that also is
native to Arucas. For example `object.copy()` will use the Arucas 'copy' function.
But this is extremely rare so almost all of the time you should all the method normally.

params.name: methodName
params.desc: the name of the method

params.name: parameters...
params.desc: the parameters to call the method with

returns.desc: the return value of the method call wrapped in the Java wrapper

methods.name: getField
deprecated: You should call the method directly on the value: `Java.constructClass('me.senseiwells.impl.Test').A;`
desc: This returns the Java wrapped value of the specified field.
There is no reason for you to be using this method, it will be removed in future versions

params.name: fieldName
params.desc: the name of the field

returns.desc: the Java wrapped value of the field

methods.name: getMethodDelegate
deprecated: Consider wrapping the method in a lambda instead
desc: This returns a method delegate for the specified method name and parameters.
This should be avoided and replaced with a Arucas function wrapping the call instead.
For example: `delegate = (fun() { Java.valueOf('').isBlank(); });`.
Another thing to note is that the parameter count parameter is no longer
used and ignored internally, instead the parameters are calculated when you
call the delegate. The parameter remains for backwards compatability.

params.name: methodName
params.desc: the name of the method

params.name: parameters
params.desc: the number of parameters

returns.desc: the function containing the Java method delegate

methods.name: setField
deprecated: You should assign the value directly on the value: Java.constructClass('me.senseiwells.impl.Test').A = 'Hello';
desc: This sets the specified field to the specified value
There is no reason for you to be using this method, it will be removed in future versions

params.name: fieldName
params.desc: the name of the field

params.name: value
params.desc: the value to set the field to, the value type must match the type of the field

methods.name: toArucas
desc: This converts the Java value to an Arucas Value if possible, this may still
be of a Java value if it cannot be converted. For example, Strings, Numbers, Lists
will be converted but

returns.desc: the Value in Arucas, this may still be of Java value if the value cannot be converted into an Arucas value, values like Strings, Numbers, Lists, etc... will be converted

Java.setStaticField('java.lang.Integer', 'MAX_VALUE', Java.intOf(100));"

JavaClass.name: JavaClass
desc: This class 'acts' as a Java class. You are able to call this class which
will invoke the Java class' constructor, and access and assign the static
fields of the class. This class cannot be instantiated or extended.

Json.name: Json
desc: This class allows you to create and manipulate JSON objects.
This class cannot be instantiated or extended

returns.desc: the Value parsed from the Json

if the file given is a directory or cannot be

static_methods.name: fromMap

any values that are not Numbers, Booleans, Lists, Maps, or Null will use their
toString() member to convert them to a string

params.name: map
params.desc: the map that you want to parse into a Json

returns.desc: the Json parsed from the map

static_methods.name: fromString
desc: This converts a string into a Json provided it is formatted correctly,
otherwise throwing an error

params.name: string
params.desc: the string that you want to parse into a Json

returns.desc: the Json parsed from the string

KeyBind.name: KeyBind
desc: This class allows you to create key binds that can be used, everything is
handled for you internally so you just need to regers the key bind and

List.name: List
desc: This class is used for collections of ordered elements
This creates a list, this cannot be called directly, only from child classes

methods.name: addAll
desc: This allows you to add all the values in another collection to the list

params.name: collection
params.desc: the collection you want to add to the list

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: append
desc: This allows you to append a value to the end of the list

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to append

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: clear
desc: This allows you to clear the list

methods.name: contains
desc: This allows you to check if the list contains a specific value

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to check

returns.desc: true if the list contains the value

methods.name: containsAll
desc: This allows you to check if the list contains all the values in another collection

params.name: collection
params.desc: the collection you want to check agains

returns.desc: true if the list contains all the values in the collection

methods.name: filter
desc: This filters the list using the predicate, a function that either returns
true or false, based on the element on whether it should be kept or not,
and returns a new list with the filtered elements

params.name: predicate
params.desc: a function that takes a value and returns Boolean

returns.desc: the filtered collection

methods.name: flatten
desc: If there are any objects in the list that are collections they will
be expanded and added to the list. However collections inside those
collections will not be flattened, this is returned as a new list

returns.desc: the flattened list

methods.name: get
desc: This allows you to get the value at a specific index, alternative to bracket accessor,
this will throw an error if the index given is out of bounds

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the value you want to get

returns.desc: the value at the index

methods.name: indexOf
desc: This allows you to get the index of a specific value

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to get the index of

returns.desc: the index of the value

methods.name: insert
desc: This allows you to insert a value at a specific index, this will throw an error if the index is out of bounds

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to insert

params.name: index
params.desc: the index you want to insert the value at

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: lastIndexOf
desc: This allows you to get the last index of a specific value

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to get the last index of

returns.desc: the last index of the value

methods.name: map
desc: This maps the list using the mapper, a function that takes a value and
returns a new value, and returns a new list with the mapped elements

params.name: mapper
params.desc: a function that takes a value and returns a new value

returns.desc: the mapped collection

methods.name: prepend
desc: This allows you to prepend a value to the beginning of the list

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to prepend

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: reduce
desc: This reduces the list using the reducer, a function that takes an
accumulated value and a new value and returns the next accumulated value

params.name: reducer
params.desc: a function that takes a value and returns a new value

returns.desc: the reduced value

methods.name: remove
desc: This allows you to remove the value at a specific index, alternative to bracket assignment.
This will throw an error if the index is out of bounds

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the value you want to remove

returns.desc: the value that was removed

methods.name: removeAll
desc: This allows you to remove all the values in another collection from the list

params.name: collection
params.desc: the collection you want to remove from the list

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: retainAll
desc: This allows you to retain only the values that are in both lists

params.name: list
params.desc: the list you want to retain values from

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: reverse
desc: This allows you to reverse the list

returns.desc: the reversed list

methods.name: set
desc: This allows you to set the value at a specific index, alternative to bracket assignment,
this will throw an erroor if the index given is out of bounds

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to set

params.name: index
params.desc: the index you want to set the value at

returns.desc: the list

methods.name: shuffle
desc: This allows you to shuffle the list

returns.desc: the shuffled list

methods.name: sort
desc: This allows you to sort the list using the elements compare method

returns.desc: the sorted list

methods.name: sort
desc: This allows you to sort the list using a comparator function

params.name: comparator
params.desc: the comparator function

returns.desc: the sorted list

LivingEntity.name: LivingEntity
desc: This class extends Entity and so inherits all of their methods too,
LivingEntities are any entities that are alive, so all mobs

desc: This gets the LivingEntity's current health

methods.name: getStatusEffects
desc: This gets the LivingEntity's status effects, you can find

[here](https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Java_Edition_data_values#Effects)

returns.desc: a list of status effects, may be empty

desc: This checks if the LivingEntity is fly falling (gliding with elytra)

Map.name: Map
desc: This class is used to create a map of objects, using keys and values.
This class cannot be directly instantiated, but can be extended to create a map of your own type.
This creates an empty map, this cannot be called directly, only from child classes

methods.name: putIfAbsent
desc: This allows you to put a key and value in the map if it doesn't exist

params.name: key
params.desc: the key you want to put

params.name: value
params.desc: the value you want to put

methods.name: remove
desc: This allows you to remove a key and its value from the map

Material.name: Material

MerchantScreen.name: MerchantScreen
desc: This class extends Screen and so inherits all of their methods too,
this class is used to add functionality to trading screens.

methods.name: clearTrade
desc: This clears the currently selected trade.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

methods.name: doesVillagerHaveTrade
desc: This checks if the villager has a trade for a certain item.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: materialLike
params.desc: the item or material to check for

returns.desc: true if the villager has a trade for the item, false otherwise

methods.name: getIndexOfTradeItem
desc: This gets the index of a trade for a certain item.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: material
params.desc: the item to get the index of

returns.desc: the index of the trade

methods.name: getPriceForIndex
desc: This gets the price of a trade at a certain index.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the trade

returns.desc: the price of the trade

methods.name: getTradeItemForIndex
desc: This gets the item stack of a trade at a certain index.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the trade

returns.desc: the item stack of the trade

methods.name: getTradeList
desc: This gets a list of all the merchant's trades

returns.desc: the list of all the Trades

methods.name: getTradeListSize
desc: This gets the size of all the trades available

returns.desc: the size of the trade list

methods.name: getVillagerLevel
desc: This gets the level of the villager, this will
throw an error if you are not trading with a villager.
The level can be between 1 - 5 from Novice to Master

returns.desc: the level of the villager

methods.name: getVillagerXp
desc: This gets the amount of xp in the villagers xp bar,
The total amount of xp is hardcoded for each level.
Level 2 requires 10 xp, 3 requires 70 (60 xp from 2 -> 3),
4 requires 150 (80 xp from 3 -> 4), 5 requires 250
(100 xp from 4 -> 5). 250 is the max xp a villager can have

returns.desc: the amount of xp

methods.name: isTradeDisabled
desc: This returns true if a trade is disabled at an index

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the trade

returns.desc: true if a trade is disabled

methods.name: isTradeSelected
desc: This returns true if a trade is selected

returns.desc: true if a trade is selected

methods.name: selectTrade
desc: This selects the currently selected trade, as if you were to click it.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the trade

methods.name: tradeIndex
desc: This makes your player trade with the merchant at a certain index.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

params.name: index
params.desc: the index of the trade

methods.name: tradeSelected
desc: This trades the currently selected trade.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

methods.name: tradeSelectedAndThrow
desc: This trades the currently selected trade and throws the items that were traded.
You must be inside the merchant GUI or an error will be thrown

MinecraftClient.name: MinecraftClient
desc: This allows for many core interactions with the MinecraftClient

methods.name: addCommand
desc: This allows you to register your own client side command in game

params.name: command
params.desc: a command map or a command builder

methods.name: canSendScriptPacket
desc: Returns whether the server supports client script packets

returns.desc: Whether the client can send packets to the server

methods.name: clearChat
desc: This will clear the chat hud

methods.name: editSign
desc: This allows you to edit sign at certain position with given string(lines), up to 4 lines.
This function does not check if sign is editable / is in position.

params.name: position
params.desc: the position of sign

params.name: string...
params.desc: the lines for the sign, requires 1 string and up to 4 strings

examples: client.editSign(new Pos(0,0,0), '100', '101', 'this is third line', 'last line');

methods.name: getClientRenderDistance
desc: This returns the current render distance set on the client

returns.desc: the render distance

methods.name: getCursorStack
desc: This returns the item stack that is currently being held by the cursor

returns.desc: the item stack, will be Air if there is nothing

methods.name: getEssentialClientValue
desc: This gets the value of the given client rule.
This will throw an error if the rule name is invalid

params.name: ruleName
params.desc: the client rule

returns.desc: the value of the client rule

methods.name: getFps
desc: This gets the current fps

returns.desc: the fps

methods.name: getLatestChatMessage
desc: This will return the latest chat message

returns.desc: the latest chat message, null if there is none

methods.name: getModList
desc: This gets a list of all the mod ids of the mods installed

returns.desc: the mod ids

methods.name: getPing
desc: This gets the current connected server's ping.
This will throw an error if the client is not connected to a server

returns.desc: the server ping in milliseconds

methods.name: getPlayer
desc: This returns the current player on the client

returns.desc: the main player

methods.name: getRunDirectory
desc: Returns the directory where the client is running

returns.desc: the Minecraft run directory

methods.name: getScriptsPath
desc: This gets the script directory path, this is where all scripts are stored

returns.desc: the script directory path

methods.name: getServerIp
desc: This will return the server ip

returns.desc: The server ip, null if in single player

methods.name: getServerName
desc: This gets the current connected server's name that you have set it to in the multiplayer screen

returns.desc: the server name

methods.name: getVersion
desc: This returns the current version of Minecraft you are playing

returns.desc: the version for example: '1.17.1'

methods.name: getWorld
desc: This returns the world that is currently being played on

returns.desc: the world

methods.name: holdKey
desc: This allows you to simulate a key being held inside of Minecraft, this will press, hold, and release.
This will throw an error if the given key is unknown

params.name: key
params.desc: the key to hold

params.name: milliseconds
params.desc: the number of milliseconds you want it held for

methods.name: isInSinglePlayer
desc: This will return true if the client is in single player mode

returns.desc: true if the client is in single player mode

methods.name: parseStringToNbt
desc: This parses a string and turns it into a Nbt compound

params.name: string
params.desc: the string to parse

returns.desc: the nbt compound as a value

methods.name: playSound
desc: This plays the given sound with the given volume and pitch around the player
sound id's can be found [here](https://minecraft.fandom.com/wiki/Sounds.json#Sound_events)

params.name: soundId
params.desc: the sound id you want to play

params.name: volume
params.desc: the volume of the sound

params.name: pitch
params.desc: the pitch of the sound

methods.name: playerNameFromUuid
desc: This will return the player name from the given uuid

params.name: uuid
params.desc: the uuid as a string

returns.desc: the player name, null if the uuid is not found

methods.name: pressKey
desc: This allows you to simulate a key press inside of Minecraft, this will only press the key down.
This will throw an error if the key is unknown

params.name: key
params.desc: the key to press

methods.name: releaseKey
desc: This allows you to simulate a key release inside of Minecraft, this
is useful for keys that only work on release, for example `F3`, this
will throw an error if the key is unknown

params.name: key
params.desc: the key to release

methods.name: renderFloatingItem
desc: This renders an item in front of the player using the totem of undying animation

params.name: material
params.desc: the material to render

methods.name: resetEssentialClientRule
desc: This resets the given client rule to its default value.
This will throw an error if the rule name is invalid

params.name: ruleName
params.desc: the client rule

methods.name: run
desc: This runs the given function on the main thread

params.name: function
params.desc: the function to run

MinecraftTask.name: MinecraftTask
desc: This class is used to create tasks that can be chained and
run on the main Minecraft thread. This ensures that all
behaviors work as intended.
This creates a new empty Minecraft task

methods.name: run
desc: This runs the task on the main Minecraft thread. It returns a future
which can be awaited, the last function in the chain will be used as
the return value for the future

returns.desc: the future value that can be awaited

examples:
task = new MinecraftTask()
    .then(fun() print("hello"))
    .then(fun() print(" "))
    .then(fun() print("world"))
    .then(fun() 10);
f = task.run(); // prints 'hello world'
print(f.await()); // prints 10

methods.name: waitThen
desc: This adds a delay (in ticks) then runs the given task.
This delay is will also affect all following chained function
delays. If this is the last function in the chain, then the
return value will be determined by this function

params.name: ticks
params.desc: the amount of ticks delay before the function runs

params.name: function
params.desc: the function to run after the delay

returns.desc: the task, this allows for chaining

examples:
task = new MinecraftTask()
    .then(fun() print("hello"))
    .waitThen(5, fun() print("world"));
task.run(); // prints 'hello', waits 5 ticks, prints 'world'

Task.name: Task
desc: This class is used to create tasks that can be chained and
run asynchronously. Tasks can be executed as many times as needed
and chained tasks will be executed in the order they are created.
This creates a new empty task

methods.name: loopIf
desc: This loops the task, essentially just calling 'task.run', the
task will run async from the original task, the loop will continue
if the function provided returns true

params.name: boolSupplier
params.desc: the function to check if the loop should run

returns.desc: the task, this allows for chaining

examples:
task = new Task()
    .then(fun() print("hello"))
    .then(fun() print(" "))
    .then(fun() print("world"))
    .loopIf(fun() true); // Always loop

methods.name: run
desc: This runs the task asynchronously and returns a future which can be awaited.
The last function in the task will be used as the return value for the future

returns.desc: the future value that can be awaited

examples:
task = new Task()
    .then(fun() print("hello"))
    .then(fun() print(" "))
    .then(fun() print("world"))
    .then(fun() 10);
f = task.run(); // prints 'hello world'
print(f.await()); // prints 10

methods.name: then
desc: This adds a function to the end of the current task.
If this is the last function in the task then the return
value of the function will be the return value of the task.

params.name: function
params.desc: the function to run at the end of the task

returns.desc: the task, this allows for chaining

examples:
task = new Task()
    .then(fun() print("hello"))
    .then(fun() print(" "))
    .then(fun() print("world"))
    .then(fun() 10);
f = task.run(); // prints 'hello world'
print(f.await()); // prints 10
